ON THE FOOD RIOTS IN DAMASCUS It is said that the reason is his relation with a woman from the women of the village. But the unknown truth is when .... for two days congregated a crowd of poor women (ijtamaʿa jamīʿ al-fuqarāʾ min al-nisāʾ) most of whom were the wives of the Redif and Mustaḥfiẓ troops. Thamarāt 21 Mar 1878 (#151)

13 Mar 1878 - admin changes - situation of the poor: the women and children, who are disabled / deprived of those who were sent to the theatres (dār al-ḥarb) and who are not relieved from the strain of hardship. particularly for the poor, who do not have any bread. as the prices of wheat and bread are dear. the poor cannot afford the raṭl of bread, the black quality of which is sold at Ps3. the bitterness at the night of parting with the thickness/ply of the bakers, their .... in poverty from which they are not relieved and nothing being done. - thus today, some of them (baʿḍahum, i.e. not necessarily the women only) went to the municipal council with the goal of obtaining a Ps1 subsidy for every raṭl of bread ... what is consumed of the kaime [i.e. reduced in value] as it is said 'there is no power nor might but in God'. - fate of the refugees is even worse.

PRO FO 226/197 Damascus Political 5, Jago to Earl of Derby, State of Affairs in Damascus, 27 Mar 1878

that is the actual report on "The state of affairs in Damascus" including the bread riots on March 16th 1878, when women stormed the serail. original to be found in FO 78/2850 Political No. 5 Vice Consul Jago to The Earl of Derby Dam.s March 27. 1878 My Lord, I have the honor to report to Y.L. that recent events having prepared the people for what is considered by them as tantamount to the collapse of Ottoman power, the news of the signing of peace between Russia & Turkey has been received here with comparative indifference. To the small Christian and Jewish communities which have unscathed [?] out of the ordeal just past through cave in occasional panics and in the heavy pecuniary losses - incidental to commercial stagnation and governmental indebtedness , the news has affoured belief from the fears generated by the war, besides hopes, too vague to to be put into shape, of some amelioration of their present position. Among the better & more affluent classes of the Moslems, few as they now are, whose means have enabled them to escape conscription if not the payment of heavy war taxation, the little sympathy which before existed with the ruling Power, springing solely out of identity of religion, has been totally extinguished by the bitter recollection of sacrifies unstinlingly [?] wrung from the country, and which now, owing, as they assert to Turkish corruption & incapacity have proved wholly in vain. To the poorest classes of the Moslem population of the settled districts which, whether urban or rural, have borne the entire brunt of the large levies made in Syria - (estimated by the military authorities at 115000 men from the Vilayets of Syria & Aleppo) - and have been besides reduced to semi starvation by the forcible abstraction of bread-winners, by war and other taxes ruthlessly levied, and by the capacity of any army of unpaid officials, no relief is apparent. They have given their all in men & money; & then ignorance & distress preclude them from entertaining hopes for the future even were such more apparent then they are. A strong disaffection against Ottoman rule pervades all classes of the Moslems but is only manifested in words. Leaders they have none. The energies of the lower classes are absorbed in eking out a bare subsistence as best they can; while the better classes bent upon preserving the little the still possess, are sunk in despondency at the prospect before them and are fain to seek consolation in the feelings of resignation peculiar to their faith. Those few who by reason of their wealth, or by their position in the religious hierarchy, are still deemed leaders, or, more properly, the heads of the people, are united only by the bond of common dislike to a government to the corruption and general departure from the strict tenets of Islam of which, they seek to ascribe all the evils which have overtaken the country. Resistance, however, passive or otherwise, to the bewests of God, in the matters of civil authority where their joint action is demanded in order to regularize governmental [...] or local exactions, is defeated by the petty rivalries & jealousies which of all times and under all circumstances exist among them to a degree to render them useless as protectors of the common interests of the people, and impotent when considered as a possible element of danger to the Ruling Power. This general feeling of discontent & disaffection against every thing Ottoman - proceeding out of recent events, shored itself forcibly on the 16.th instant & following days when owing to a rise in the already high price of bread, a mob of women, chiefly the families of departed Radifs, stormed the Seraïl of Damascus, the official residence of Djevdet Pasha, the newly appointed Gov.r Gen. of Syria. Bitter curses upon the Sultan & his Gov.t for the evils which have lately fallen upon the land were liberally showered upon the Pasha, as well as allusions to the corruption of the administration in general and of Governors General in particular. Reproaches for the losses of their male relatives were interspersed with hopes from the more desperate that the Russians would take Syria & thus relieve them from the curse upon them. These sentiments are the echo of public opinion in Damascus expressing itself in a manner peculiar to the people. Displays of fanatical temper towards Christians during Turkish successes, slight as they were owing to the vigilance of the Commander in Chief in compelling the action of the Police, ceased with the news of the reverses; and past & present sufferings combined with the uncertainty of future relief seem to have eradicated, for the present at least, any tendency to assume a superiority, formerly believed in by the bigoted and ignorant and often worked upon by interested parties, but now under the pressure of actual circumstances tacitly abandoned. The Christians & Jews of Syria have escaped in a high degree the evils which have so disastrously pressed upon their less favored Moslem brethren. Moral pressure alone has been use in respect of the never ending so called voluntary war taxes so ruthlessly levied upo the Moslems; & the quota they have subscribe has been out of all proportion to what they have been asked for. In fact what they have given has simply been to save appearances. The Civil administration of the Vilayet since the beginning of the war has existed only in name. Corruption & administrative [...] have been glaring even for Syria & seem to have increased in inverse proportion to the reverser of the Turkish arms. And although the virtual stoppage of pay of employes has no doubt much to answer for, it can hardly be held as a sufficient excuse for the unblushing manner n which the necessities of the people arising out of war burdens, and Imperial Interests, have been trade upon for personal profit by the officials of this Province, high & low, to the detriment of the Gov.t in its hour of need and to the grinding & impoverishment of all those whose lack of position or means failed to protect them. Orders have been received from Constantinople to disband the Mustafiz now under arms. Execution, however, has been suspended pending the return of regular troops to Syria. The force of regular troops kept here during the war has been 2 battalions of Infantry; one at Dam.s & the other disposed of throughout the Province to serve as the backbone for raw and aged local levies. Besides theses are the mounted Zaptiehs or Rural Police numbering nominally 1800 men, but really, owing to non- payment of wages, about 900 effectives. This small force has sufficed to preserve order, and to crush, without serious collision, inciffcent [?] attempts at resistance against governmental exigencies in men or taxes of some of the more unruly of the inhabitants; and it shows forcibly both the great prestige which the Ottoman Power still obtains as a repressive agency in spie of its present situation, and the want of cohesion among the heterogenous elements composing the population of Syria. Consular influence in this great Mohamedan centre was naturally much restricted during the war by political events. The Corps was however brought up to its full strength by the appointments of an Italian and of Spanish Consul as well as of a German Vice Consul; although the little influence possessed by this British Vice Consulate was perhaps not more conspicuous than that of the agents of other Powers the far greater number of persons under its protection, and the importance of their suspending claims amounting in the aggrega to about £ 280,000, caused the inaction of the administration to be more severely felt by the British than by other nationalities. Since the arrival the other day of Djevdet Pasha, the new Governor General, the machinery of the Civil Government has once more been set in motion & as marked change for the better, in respect of administration routine at least, is apparent. Save the article of bread the necessaries of life are very cheap. The coming harvests promise to be unusually abundant. They will not, however, be available for two months. Damascus, the surrounding country, including the Hauran, continues to enjoy perfect tranquillity despite the general discontent & the distress and I have been unable to discover any foundation for the disquieting though vague rumors which have recently appeared in the European Press regarding Syria. I have [...] (signed) T.S. Jago V.Consul

Levant Herald 28 Mar 1878 (vol.X, #73)

A letter from Beirut Mar.18, reporting on the sinking of the vessel Sphinx with 3.000 Circassian refugees onboard in the waters of Cyprus. The author comments on the influx of these refugees in Syria and Beirut, where only 2.000 of them arrived. Finally he describes the situation at Damascus as devastating and that women stormed the palace in demand for bread.

A letter from Beirut Mar.18, reporting on the sinking of the vessel Sphinx with 3.000 Circassian refugees onboard in the waters of Cyprus. Levant Herald 11 Apr 1878 (vol.X, #85)

"Le Hadikat-ul-Akhbar [ḥadīqat al-akhbār], journal official publié à Beyrouth, dit qu'une réunion d'indigents et de pauvres s'est tenue la semaine dernière devant le sérail du gouvernement à Damas, en faisant entendre des murmures et des plaintes contre la rareté du pain, la mauvaise qualité de celui livré à la consommation, jointe à l'excessive élévation du prix, et cela vu l'absence des céréales que des entrepreneurs avaient emmagasinées a qu'ils refusaient de livrer au marché. Le vali, Djevdet pacha, se rendit immédiatement au Conseil administratif et concerta les mesures nécessaires pour faire cesser cet état de choses. Les magasins du Méidan remplis de blé ont été ouverts au marché et les boulangers ont pu ainsi se fournier du blé qui leur était nécessaire et livrer à la consommation une bonne qualité de blé, à un prix relativement fort réduit."

Thamarāt 16 Mar 1880 (#272)

BREAD RIOT IN BEIRUT: "tamma baʿda an ʿalam al-khāṣṣ wa al-ʿāmm mādhā ḥadatha ʿalā al-nuqūd ..." as all strata heard about the fate of the money, the poor helped themselves to bread when the bakeries and public ovens where closed on Friday morning. literally: the poor attacked (fa-hajamat al-ahālī min al-fuqarāʾ ʿalayhā) the closed bakeries and stores. - Mutaṣarrif established exchange rates

Lisān 21 Aug 1908 (#5795)

yesterday: bread riot in Beirut:Large numbers of poor and destitute gathered yesterday morning (ijtamaʿa awwal ams jumhūr kabīr min al-fuqarāʾ wa arbāb al-ʿayyāl) in front of the Serai in Beirut. They called for help and lamented (yastaghīthūna wa yatawasilūna) the current situation and called for the lowering of prices of Ṭaḥīn and Bread to ease their suffering and those of all other poor, especially since most flour merchants, sellers of Ṭaḥīn, owners of ovens and bakeries (makhābiz) already tyrannise them and profit from sunflower bread (quwat al-ʿabād) in a clear breach of all laws and legal prescriptions (jamīʿ al-qawānīn wa al-sharāʾiʿ) until the raṭl of bread was sold at more then Ps 7,5. This is contrary to justice (al-ʿadāla) and no one can [possibly] accept this. When their [yelling of] complaints grew and their shouting and screaming rose, the vigorous Anīs Efendi Ramaḍān, superintendent of the police, went out to meet them. He soothed their minds with a speech full of courtesy and refinement. He assured them that the authorities directed its zeal and efforts to the lowering of the bread prices / prices of foodstuffs (asʿār al-quwat) and thus they withdraw gratefully.Their agreement had almost held until they were met by a group of their likes (jamāʿat min amthālihim), wretched and poor (arbāb al-ʿayāl wa al-fuqarāh).Together they went to the customs demonstrating in the same manner as the last time, scattering the flour on the floor and preventing its export from the province and killing (yaftakūna) everyone who tried to stop them. Their threatening and menacing was not stopped until the director of the police and assured them of the seriousness of the [governments efforts] to secure the necessary funds and ease the price of food (al-maʾkūlāt). He explained everything and how it would take less than 10 days for the Ṭaḥīn calamity to ease as well as all other calamities that they complained of. And thus they were appeased.yesterday they again gathered (ijtimāʿ) and decided amongst them to repeat their demonstrations (muẓāharāt) today. Thus they roamed (yaṭūfū) the stores of flour (sāḥat al-qamḥ) and all other places where Ṭaḥīn is sold and they also demonstrated in expression of their dissatisfaction with the high prices of meat etc."- short statement on Lisā's position on the matter

PRO FO 371/560 Baghdad, Major Ramsay to Government of India, 21 Sep 1908

(44/F37953/08) Therapia 721, 27 Oct 1908, Lowther "Wheat Riots at Baghdad, Major Bemsay’s No 864 reporting on" Enclosing the despatch by the Consul General in Baghdad #Inclosure no. 1 Bagdad, 21 Sep 1908, Major Ramsay to Government of India "Sir, In continuation of my letter [No. 847] dated the 14th instant, I have the honour to report that the telegram of which the purport was given in the third paragraph of that letter appears to have been malevolently added to in Bagdad before it was made partially public. The original telegram, as received from Constantinople, contained no reference to the use of military force against the Young Turk Committee in provincial towns. The perverted version of the telegram was made known in Karbala. 2. On the 16th instant there was a riot in which some of the grain stored were pillaged. The exportation of wheat has for some time been prohibited, and on the 14th and 15th instant it was rumoured that a certain Jew had received permission from Constantinople to export some wheat and that he was going to load it on the 16th. On that morning a crowd went to the Vali to protest. It is said that the Vali assured them that no order had been issued allowing the export of wheat, and it is said that the Vali strengthened his assurance by saying that when an attempt to load wad made it would time for the people to make serious complaints. It is not possible to know exactly what was said, much less what was understood, but the crowd went straight off to the grain stores and took what they could carry. It was at first reported that the loss was enormous, but the estimates have since been largely reduced, and I am inclined to think that the loss cannot have been very great. The populace took what it could during an interval of about an hour and a-half, but the entrances to the store are narrow and they were choked by the crowd, so much so that a number of the rioters found it convenient to pass their stolen wheat over the wall. In these circumstances a very large quantity of wheat cannot have been removed. Messrs. Lynch’s experience is that with the best arrangement, and all wheat in bags, not more than 100 tons could be removed in an hour and a-half. A very small proportion of this can have been taken by a struggling crowd. One man claimed compensation for about 600l. [£ 600] worth of wheat which he said he held on behalf of a British subject and which he said had been pillaged during the riot. I went to his place of business to examine his books, and he then said that he did not want the intervention of the Consulate and would settle the matter himself. Another man who claimed compensation on behalf of Messrs. Andrew Weir and Co. of London had to admit that he could not produce proof that any Court would accept. A third man’s claim is still under consideration, but from what I have heard I am pretty fairly certain that it will not stand examination. There is no doubt that all of these men have lost wheat, but they cannot prove that it was the property of British subjects. 3. There are a number of deserters about Bagdad who are a continual source of danger to peaceful people. I understand that the Commander of the VIth Army Corps has written to Constantinople to say that it is necessary either to come to some settlement with them or to shoot them. 4. The Young Turk Committee at Karbala has made all the officials publicly swear loyalty to the Constitution, but the Mutessarif shows a strong dislike to interference, and the Vali of Bagdad is said to be troubled with many differences between the two parties. I have, &c. …

PRO FO 371/560 Damascus 51, Devey to Lowther, Quarterly Report, 1 Oct 1908

(44/F37930/08)Therapia 697, 24 Oct 1908, Lowther to"Quarterly report on Damascus" Printed for considerationInclosure: Damascus 51, 1 Oct 1908, Devey to Lowther. Printed version & type written version[…]"the great ‘coup d’Etat’ which took place in Turkey on the 24th July occupied all minds and arouses every emotion with the proclamation of the Constitution, in Damascus as in all other important centres in the Empire. Among its results worthy of remark here were (a) celebrations and festivities (b) dismissal or resignation of notoriously corrupt officials (c) formation of clubs and associations (d) parliamentary elections (e) reforms in various governmental departments. (f) release or rehabilitation of political exiles or persons [xxx].Rejoicings and joyful manifestation are only coming now to an end, after lasting more than two months: more than 25 well organized great meetings were held int he different quarters of the city, mostly attended by several thousands [sic] demonstrators and spectators, and hundreds of speeches were delivered, all condemning autocracy as despotic & tyrannical and eulogizing liberty and constitutional government. About £2000 were spent on the festivities and had not notables of Damascus with the young Turks lately recommended their cessation they might have continued for another month or more. It is to be remarked with pleasure that all these gathering & demonstrations were conducted most orderly without any dispute or ill feeling among those who assembled.Many corrupt officials were either dismissed or withdrew themselves.The Alaybey of Gendarmerie, the Chief of Police, the Muhassebeji, six Caimacams of Cazas, Moh.d P. Adm [Muḥammad Pasha al-ʿAẓm] of Idara Mejliss with about 30 other minor officials vacated their posts, mostly to the general satisfaction of the public and it is debated now among ‘Young Turkey’ adherents whether it would be right to punish the officials who were led to bribery by the littleness of their pay & its frequent irregularity. Doubtless the proper course will be followed in leaving this matter to the jurisdiction of Parliament when it assembles, and the ignorious[?] dismissal of the more corrupt, rapacious & outrageous among officials suffices for the moment. Moreover, the vacancies are not being easily filled up by really good substitutes, for such persons are at present rare, and often unwilling to serve. Damascus Clubs & associations, besides the Union & Progress number now five viz Hurriyet, Ulema, Medical, Commercial, Free Ottoman besides a Shoemaker guild. the first two are showing much activity wh.[ich] is likely to excite mutation . The misapprehension & with uncalled solicitude Ulema are anxious to comcure [?sic] & uphold Islam against the liberal views of the Young Turks, while the latter have no intention at present to interfere with religious precepts. There is little record as to practical work effected [?] by other clubs though their moral influence cannot be other than good.The Parliamentary elections are under preparation the last two months and in some cazas the voters have already voted for the electors, but in Damascus city this process will begin in a week’s time. It is not even announced yet how many deputies will represent this Vilayet in the Parliament but it is supposed that they will be seven or eight. The Hauran people still reject their privilege to elect a deputy and the efforts of the government in dissuading them from this self-inflicted loss seem to be futile. The Mutessarif of Kerak lately resigned on grounds of health, but before doing so had been able to set going a local society or club for instruction of the people of his district who indeed are little less backward &ignorant than this of Hauran.The reforms in the various departments of the government proceed slowly. The Municipality suppressed most improperly awarded pensions paid to persons doing nothing for it and succeeded in amassing about £3000 through various economies. The Public Instruction Department formed a new chamber to consider the reorganization of the educational system in this Vilayet. In the departments no special reforms worth mentioning have been introduced but many are being talked of & discussed. The political exiles who had been releases or rehabilitated included many persons of rank, both military and civil. Mushir Fuad Pasha’s release was the occasion of great demonstrations in Damascus, but the rehabilitation of others, with a few exceptions, was not publicly noticed, for this disgraces persons were always enjoying personal freedom and a very few persons knew that they were ‘Ikamet Mamours’ [iqāma maʾmūr]. The chief names among these were, Nouri P. Ferik of Cavalry, another Ferik called Nouri Pasha sent to live here without duties, Ferik Ibrahim Pasha (those three Feriks kept for Constantinople), Ferik Lt. Osman P., Liva Behjet Pasha (those two died recently), Colonel Bedri Bey (now of Liva Bedri P. in Constantinople). The Maàriz Mushiri [?] & his assistant, and many minor officials or private persons; such as members of the Bedr Khan family, numbering more than a hundred. Further as reported in desp. No. 32, the Ismailians subjected to religious persecution were pardoned. Happily no sort of disorder or riotous intention was displayed here for the purpose of releasing prisoners and ordinary criminals generally, as took place in some other places."Ḥijāz railway was completed in seven years and inaugurated on 1 Sep 1908. four of the five battalions employed for earthworks on the line were allowed to return to their garrisons. "about 1400 of these battalions on expiry of service were disbanded. Moreover, the four battalions of the 40th Reg, sent to Medina from this Army Corps in June last, to guard the line, are also ordered back to their headquarters. At present only two battalions are to be kept there to take care of the line as regards repairs & protection." No aspirations to commence construction beyond Medina due to increasing Bedouin raids "Public security in the Vilayet has been during the quarter satisfactory and order was properly kept. The Bedouins have been quiet & peaceful during the summer, and only on two or three occasions made petty rais & drove or carried away animals or goods but the spoils were restored to their owners without great difficulties." Druze and Bedouins seem under the spell of the government and calmly wait for the implementation of the promised reforms"the crops this year were in general very good and the grain harvest in most of the districts of the Province was exceptionally abundant. The apricot produce was above the average while walnuts were much below. All prices of fruit and cereals are still high and the peasants this year will do well. An exception might be mentioned as as regards locusts which made a perceptible damage in the Kalamoun district but had a very slight effect in some other Cazas. But the loss to the Vilayet in general has been small.As respects trade, no special remarks need be made; strikes at Beirut at the Customs and on local railways have produced only exiguous loss here. With reference to the latter we may note that public opinion judges that the smaller employés were underpaid, while the profits of the Company & of its directors were considerable and the public at the same time ill served.Public health has been satisfactory on the whole this summer, but the Ain Fijeh water has not been received the general approbation anticipated which is to be regretted, as theres is absolute proof the it is the best & purest spring water of al this neighbourhood. Its distribution to all quarters of the city proceeds slowly."

Lisān 23 Jun 1910 (#6359)

Aleppo, al-taqaddum: - BREAD RIOT: extremely dear prices of cereals. the shunbul of flour sold at Ps 170 [possibly misprint, should be Ps 70] and today it is at Ps 80. this is due to hoarding. a certain ʿAbd al-Raḥmān Efendi Jasir bought a large quantity of flour and in result the prices hiked to Ps 120. A large crowd then formed and attacked the latter's store. etc.

Jarīdat al-muqtabas 3 Jul 1910 (#412)

Yesterday forenoon gathered crowds of women (katharat jumūʿ al-nisāʾ) in front of the Serai, howling and shouting in their opposition (shākiyyāt) to the very high bread prices. Announcing their points with cries and howls. In the morning the callers/ announcers (munād) had been circling the city inviting the people (al-nās) to the gathering (ijtimāʿ) and stirring the emotions about their situation being effected by the steep increase of prices. Within an hour the streets were packed, with the women leading [the demonstration] and the men behind them as a backup force / like to force of the noon (ka-quwwat al-ẓahr). As the authorities (ḥukūma) became wary/afraid of the developments, their asked for the support of soldiers. Some of their officers commanded the law enforcement troops (al-ḍabṭ wa al-rabṭ) to check/meet those crowds (jumūʿ) with force. Thanks to God that they managed to disperse them through threatening, light beating, and occasional sloshing of water from the pump. Then they returned/retreated and nothing resulted from this [event] but the insult and abuse of some grain (ṭaḥīn) traders in town. The provincial administration already mailed the sancaks of Hamah and Ḥawrān to send all their wheat stores [to Damascus] and to Beirut to supply its stores of flour. The municipality set the price (saʿʿrat) for a raṭl of good bread to Ps3"30 and took measures against (ḍarabat ʿalā īday man …) those grain traders and millers who attempted to impose a monopoly. Likewise the province issued firm instructions to the Ḥawrān to prevent/ban Damascene traders and others from buying the wheat from its fields and transporting it to destinations other than Damascus, as had been their custom for the last years. Thus, yesterday, the price for a bushel of good wheat reached Ps53 and is expected to fall further during these two days when new cereals arrive on the market.

Jarīdat al-muqtabas 4 Jul 1910 (#413)

3hd, a person from Mīdān wrote to them about the neglect of the municipality towards cleaning the streets and alleys from rubbish and thus the neglect of public health hd, some intellectuals are of the opinion that prices of cereals would decrease if the authorities hurried the collection of the tithe and thus forced the peasants to sell their stocks. we will watch further developments hd, yesterday: the Vali invited the dignitaries and the notables of the town to the lobby (ردهة) of the Serai and after informing them that the people (ahālīn) have the right to gather and to demand their right of petition guaranteed by the law, he explained them what results from such gatherings (ijtimāʿ) as the one the day before: harm/distress to the homeland (iḍrār ʿalā al-waṭan), because it was not legal and that they were responsible. meaning being that they are the notables of the land (bilād) and its heads and it must be their desire to counsel the people (al-ahālīn) in a language (lisān) they understand that it is not advisable to rep at their actions. and they answered his question. in the same way he gathered the Imāms (īmat) of the quarters and their mukhtars and stressed his point accordingly. - he also wrote yesterday to various areas calling on them to deliver wheat and suggested to ban the export of any products that could secure the daily livelihood (ḥajiyyāt) of Dam. and thus the issue is possible peacefully concluded. hd, informed that this year's harvest in the Ḥawrān yielded much less than last year's and that the Ḥawrānese called on the authorities to lower the tithe from 25.000 kile of wheat to 15.000 ... authorities did not yield to this demand. circassian officials are ordered to enforce the tithe hd, yesterday arrived the Hahambashi of Istanbul, received with all due honours by the authorities and his community [full note]

Lisān 5 Jul 1910 (#6369)

(wrongly marked as 2 Jul in my photos)Damascus: - BREAD RIOT: the prices of flour and wheat are very high and the poor are destitute. The women gathered in front of the Serai, shouting and howling in critique of the prices of bread and flour, carrying small boys and infant girls on their arms as if they [...زغب القطا]. # Damaskus, J.Nr. 342, 16 Mar 1918, to , Ambassador in Constantinople- two attachments: Erlass vom 23. Januar d.J. - II 474 -Sending a copy of Dr. Zellner's draft of a plan to increase the production of wheat, barley, and Durrah in Syria ("Entwurf eines Planes zur Hebung der Produktion von Weizen, Gerste und Durrha in Syrien"). The author deems the plan illusionary as Syria isn't governed by a European power and points to various omissions / errors in Zellner's plan, namely that already in times of peace Syria had imported wheat from overseas. The area of land under the plough has decreased and the state collects at least ⅛ of cereals in taxes and another ⅛ in forced sales at set prices. Half the conscripted men have deserted and returned to their homes and toil the fields. The suggestion to employ soldiers for fieldwork cannot be implemented. In addition there exist no comprehensive lists of conscripted soldiers, their trades etc. "Die Ernährungsschwierigkeiten Syrien's [sic] sind bekannt; sie sind im Laufe des Krieges immer schlimmer geworden und drohen sich nunmehr zu einer Katastrophe auszuwachsen .""Herr Zeller glaubt, dass es Listen der Landarbeiter in der Armee und über die Bevölkerung in den einzelnen Bezirken gibt. Ich nehme bestimmt an, dass solche Listen nicht vorhanden sind; sollte dies trotzdem der Fall sein, so sind die Zusammenstellungen sicher gefälscht. ""Die Ernährungsfrage ist hier in der allerletzten Zeit in ein ganz kritisches Stadium getreten. habe ich auf anderem Wege gemeldet, dass () betragen hatte, innerhalb weniger Tage war. In den letzten tagen hat ein neuer gewaltiger Sprung nach oben stattgefunden: . Derartige Preise bedeuten Hungersnot für den ärmeren Teil der Bevölkerung, der sich mit Vorräten bis zur neuen Ernte nicht hat versehen können. Es scheint, dass auch die Depots der Regierung leer sind, sodass selbst die Ernährung der Armee ernstlich in Frage gestellt sein würde.Die Schuld an dieser riesigen und plötzlichen Preissteigerung ist von der öffentlichen Meinung zunächst den Getreideankäufen in die Schuhe geschoben worden, die die deutsche Etappe der Heeresgruppe F hier vorgenommen hat. Es ist richtig, dass die Etappe hier Getreide gekauft und über den Marktpreis bezahlt hat. Sie ist bei der Auswahl ihrer Aufkäufer nicht vorsichtig genug gewesen und diese haben sich ungeschickt und betrügerisch benommen, Im ganzen hat die Etappe aber, so weit ich habe ermitteln können, nur wenig über 300 Tonnen gekauft und die Aufkäufe bereits vor 2 Monaten eingestellt. Es liegt also auf der Hand, dass die 300 von deutscher Seite und vor längerer Zeit gekauften Tonnen Getreide die Preisverhältnisse auf dem sehr bedeutenden Damaszener Markt nicht tief berühren und keines Falles eine Preissteigerung wie geschehen herbeiführen können. Ich habe deshalb den Wali gebeten, den hier umlaufenen Gerüchten, wonach die Deutschen an der Steigerung der Getreidepreise schuld seien, in der Presse entgegen zu treten. Ein daraufhin in der hiesigen Zeitung "Esch Schark" [al-Sharq] veröffentlichter Leitartikel ist in französischer Uebersetzung ganz ergebenst beigefügt. Der Wali beabsichtigte, einen ähnlichen Artikel in der amtlichen Zeitung "Surija" [Sūriye] zu veröffentlichen, ich habe aber geglaubt, davon abraten zu sollen, um der Sache nicht allzugrosse Bedeutung beizulegen. Der wahre Grund für die plötzliche Steigerung der hiesigen Getreidepreise scheint darin zu liegen, dass die Drusen im Dschebel Drus, die einzigen, die noch über bedeutende Getreidevorräte verfügen, von hiesigen Spekulanten angestiftet worden sind, mit ihren Zufuhren nach Damaskus aufzuhören. Im Hauran sind grösserer Vorräte nicht mehr vorhanden. Der grosse Djemal Pascha hatte nach der vorigen Ernte wohl den Drusen, nicht aber den Hauranesen gestattet, Getreide nach Damaskus auszuführen. Er hoffte auf diese Weise den Heeresbedarf an Getreide billig im Hauran zu erhalten. Die Folge aber ist gewesen, dass die Hauranesen ihre gesamten Vorräte an die Drusen verkauft haben.Der Notlage abzuhelfen sehe ich nur drei Wege:1. _Stärkere Heranziehung der im Drusengebirge noch vorhandenen reichlichen Vorräte._ Da die Drusen von der türkischen Regierung tatsächlich unabhängig sind und da infolgedessen Zwang nicht angewandt werden kann, kann auf diesem Wege ein Erfolg nur erreicht werden, wenn sehr grosse Mittel in Gold zur Verfügung gestellt werden.2. _Stärkere Zufuhren von Norden_ (aus dem Gebiete von Konia oder gar Russland), die sich vielleicht ermöglichen liessen, falls die Leistungsfähigkeit der Eisenbahn durch Zuführung von Steinkohle als Heizmaterial entsprechend erhöht werden könnte.3. _Vergrösserung der Anbaufläche._ Da die türkische Beamtenschaft weder geändert noch beiseite geschoben werden kann, erscheint es aussichtslos, dass der Bauer zu stärkerem Anbau bewogen werden könnte. Dagegen wäre es an sich möglich, vorhandene weite und fruchtbare Landstriche mit Dampf- oder Motorpflügen zu bestellen. Eine ganze Anzahl Dampfpflüge sollen in der Gegend von Adana unbenützt herumstehen. Ein derartiges Unternehmen würde aber nur dann Aussicht auf Erfolge haben, wenn es deutscherseits in die Hand genommen würde und wenn die deutsche Leitung das Recht erhielte, die geeigneten Arbeiter aus den Deserteuren (alle arbeitsfähigen Männer, die nicht in der Front stehen sind Deserteure) selbst herauszusuchen und mit Bescheinigungen (Wessikas) zu versehen, die sie vor Zugriffen der der [sic] türkischen Behörden schützen. Bei einer derartigen Ordnung der Angelegenheit würde die türkische Beamtenschaft nichts verdienen. Die deutsche Leitung würde infolgedessen selbstverständlich gegen die wütendsten Chikanen [sic] zu kämpfen haben.–Durch ein Beschreiten des Weges zu 1. & 2. würde an sich verhätlinismässig rasch eine Besserung der hiesigen Ernährungslage erreicht werden können. Der Weg zu 3., auf dem eine ganze Anzahl Vorarbeiten unvermeidlich sind, könnt erst nach einiger Zeit zum Ziele führen.-Im gegenwärtigen Augenblicke tut schnelle Hilfe, not denn in den nächsten 3 Monaten, d.h. bis zur Ernte, ist nicht zu erwarten, dass von selbst eine Besserung der Lage eintritt. Der Mangel an Getreide und die hohen Preise haben bereits zu kleinen Revolten vor den Bäckerläden geführt. (). Die Armee soll nur noch 250 g Brot für den Mann und den Tag erhalten, eine Menge, die nicht genügt, den einfachen Soldaten, der so gut wie nichts anderes zu essen bekommt, bei zu Kräften zu erhalten. Aus der schlechten Ernährung erklären sich die vielen Desertionen und daraus wieder die ausserordentliche Schwäche der türkischen Gefechtsstärke, die dem Gegner das Spiel so leicht macht.-Der hiesige Wali, dem das gesamte Verpflegungswesen Syriens, sowohl das für die Armee wie das für die Zivilbevölkerung untersteht, hat sich unter diesen Umständen entschlossen, den Weg zu beschreiten, der theoretisch die schnellste Abhilfe verspricht. Er will sich in den nächsten Tagen nach Deraa begeben und versuchen, grössere Getreidemengen aus dem Hauran und dem Drusengebirge schleunigst nach Damaskus zu leiten. Ich glaube nicht, dass der Wali grossen Erfolg haben wird. Der Hauran kann keine nennenswerten Mengen Getreide mehr liefern und die Drusen werden sich schwer hüten, dir Früchte ihrer Spekulation aufzugeben. Sie werden Ausflüchte machen und hintertreiben, dass schnell grosse Mengen von Getreide nach Damaskus kommen. So wird es besten Falles gelingen, die hiesigen Lebensmittelpreise (wie es immer und überall der Fall ist, sind die Preise der übrigen Nahrungsmittel dem Steigen der Brotpreise gefolgt) ein wenig herabzudrücken, gewiss aber nicht soweit, dass dem armen Teil des Volkes wirklich geholfen wäre. Ich fürchte, dass die nächsten 3 Monate für die Bevölkerung Syriens traurige sein werden.Ueber die neue Ernte denkt der hiesige Wali sehr optimistisch. Er nimmt als sicher an, dass sie gut werden und dass er aus dem Wilajet Damaskus , aus dem Wilajet Aleppo und aus dem Wilajet Beirut Getreide erhalten wird. Er meint allerdings dass zur Beschaffung zum Ankauf dieser Mengen die Verausgabung von 1000000 Ltq. Gold nötig werden wird. Ich glaube unter keinen Umständen daran, dass die genannten Mengen Getreide werden aufgebracht werden können. Die Ernteaussichten sind augenblicklich allerdings günstige, günstigere als im Vorjahre. Aus den Gründen, die ich oben geschildert habe (Verringerung der Anbaufläche u.s.w.) wird trotzdem der Ausfall im kommenden Wirtschaftsjahre grösser werden als im alten. Die neue Ernte wird mit höheren Anfangspreise realisiert werden müssen als die des Vorjahres () und im Lauf der Zeit werden die Preise noch höher steigen als diesmal. Es erscheint mir daher nötig, dass sobald wie möglich auch das Beschreiten der zu 2. & 3. [sic] geschilderten Wege (Stärkere Zufuhren von Norden und Bestellung von Brachland mit Dampfpflügen) ins Auge gefasst wird. Im Hinblick auf den Widerstand, dem die Ausgaben grosser Mengen Gold in Syrien begegnen muss, und auf die grossen Schwierigkeiten, die der Erhöhung der Eisenbahnleistung entgegenstehen, wird es sich meines Erachtens nicht umgehen lassen, auch den Weg zu 3. einzuschlagen, wenn der Krieg in Syrien im Jahre 1919 fortgesetzt werden soll."
